verbs.description: abridge (third-person singular simple present abridges, present participle abridging, simple past and past participle abridged)

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To deprive; to cut off. [First attested from around (1150 to 1350)]
(transitive, archaic, rare) To debar from. [First attested from around (1150 to 1350)]
(transitive) To make shorter; to shorten in duration or extent. [First attested from around (1350 to 1470)]
examples: She retired her self to Sebaste, and abridged her train from State to necessity.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To shorten or contract by using fewer words, yet retaining the sense; to epitomize; to condense[First attested in 1384.]. [First attested from around (1350 to 1470)]
examples: It was still necessary for the man who had been formerly saluted by the highest authority as dictator of the English language to supply his wants by constant toil. He abridged his Dictionary. He proposed to bring out an edition of Shakespeare by subscription, and many subscribers sent in their names and laid down their money; but he soon found the task so little to his taste that he turned to more attractive employments.

entries.meaning: (transitive) Cut short; truncate. [First attested from around (1350 to 1470)]
(transitive) To curtail. [First attested from around (1350 to 1470)]
examples: He had his rights abridged by the crooked sheriff.
